verses.text: Woe to you, destroyer, who have not been destroyed; and you who deal treacherously, though they have not dealt treacherously with you! When you finish destroying, you will be destroyed; when you have finished dealing treacherously, they will deal treacherously with you.
verses.comment: This verse delivers a warning against oppressors and betrayers, likely addressing Assyria. The justice of God is highlighted, promising that evil actions will return upon the perpetrator (cf. Matthew 7:2).

verses.text: O LORD, be gracious to us; we wait for you. Be our arm every morning, our salvation in the time of trouble.
verses.comment: A prayer for God's mercy and strength each day. 'Arm' is a metaphor for God's power to save. This anticipates the ultimate salvation found in Christ.

verses.text: At the sound of tumult, peoples flee; at your lifting yourself up, nations scatter.
verses.comment: God's appearance causes fear and confusion among enemy nations. The theme is repeated throughout scripture, showing God's sovereignty over history.

verses.text: Your spoil is gathered as the caterpillar gathers; as locusts leap, men leap upon it.
verses.comment: The plundering of Assyria is likened to insects devouring crops—swift and overwhelming. This alludes to divine judgment against those who oppose God’s people.

verses.text: The LORD is exalted, for he dwells on high; he will fill Zion with justice and righteousness.
verses.comment: The holiness and transcendence of God are emphasized. Justice and righteousness link to the coming Kingdom, foreshadowing Christ’s reign. God's dwelling in Zion prepares for the full revelation of his presence among his people.

verses.text: He will be the stability of your times, abundance of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge; the fear of the LORD is his treasure.
verses.comment: True security and wisdom come from God. This verse connects wisdom, salvation, and the proper reverence for God, which is a central theme of the Scriptures.

verses.text: Behold, their brave men cry outside; the envoys of peace weep bitterly.
verses.comment: The anguish of leaders and messengers shows the nation’s distress while under siege, reflecting how reliance on human negotiation falls short compared to God’s deliverance.

verses.text: The highways are deserted; travelers have ceased. The covenant is broken, witnesses are despised, there is no regard for man.
verses.comment: The devastation includes shattered trust and lawlessness. The failed covenant likely refers to broken treaties, showing the spiritual and moral decline accompanying physical destruction.

verses.text: The land mourns and languishes; Lebanon is put to shame and withers; Sharon is like a desert, and Bashan and Carmel shake off their leaves.
verses.comment: Nature itself suffers as a consequence of the nation’s sin, reinforcing that God’s judgment affects all creation. These fertile regions turning desolate highlights the seriousness of turning from God.

verses.text: "Now I will arise," says the LORD, "Now I will lift myself up; now I will be exalted."
verses.comment: God personally intervenes when human strength is exhausted. This dramatic intervention foreshadows the final, visible coming of God in judgment and salvation.

verses.text: You conceive chaff, you give birth to stubble; your breath, as fire, will consume you.
verses.comment: Human plans apart from God are empty and self-destructive. The metaphor shows that rebellious efforts produce only ruin.

verses.text: The peoples will be burned as if to lime, like thorns cut down, that are burned in the fire.
verses.comment: Judgment imagery: nations opposed to God are compared to thorns thrown on the fire—complete destruction, which echoes final judgment themes in the New Testament.

verses.text: "Hear, you who are far off, what I have done; and you who are near, acknowledge my might."
verses.comment: All peoples are called to witness God's works. Emphasizes God's universal authority, preparing the way for the gospel being preached to the nations (Luke 24:47).

verses.text: The sinners in Zion are afraid; trembling has seized the godless: "Who among us can dwell with the consuming fire? Who among us can dwell with everlasting burnings?"
verses.comment: God’s holiness is a cause for fear apart from atonement. The 'consuming fire' represents God's righteous judgment—language picked up in Hebrews regarding God’s unchanging nature.

verses.text: He who walks righteously and speaks uprightly, who despises the gain of oppression, who shakes his hands, lest they hold a bribe, who stops his ears from hearing of bloodshed and shuts his eyes from looking on evil—
verses.comment: This describes those who can endure God's presence—those who practice justice and righteousness. Echoes Psalm 15. Holiness requires not just faith but ethical action, a point affirmed by the apostles (James 2:14-18).

verses.text: he will dwell on the heights; his place of defense will be the fortresses of rocks; his bread will be given him, his water will be sure.
verses.comment: The faithful are protected and provided for. God’s provision is spiritual and physical. The language echoes God feeding his people in the wilderness.

verses.text: Your eyes will see the King in his beauty; they will behold a land that stretches afar.
verses.comment: The promised vision points to the Messiah as King. The 'land far off' suggests the coming reign of God with blessings for his people (see Matthew 5:8 for seeing God).

verses.text: Your heart will muse on the terror: "Where is he who counted? Where is he who weighed the tribute? Where is he who counted the towers?"
verses.comment: In the time of God’s salvation, those who oppressed and threatened are gone. Believers will recall their former fears as things now past, highlighting God’s mighty deliverance.

verses.text: You will see no more the fierce people, a people of obscure speech that you cannot comprehend, stammering in tongue that you cannot understand.
verses.comment: The oppressors (Assyrians) are removed. The reference to 'obscure speech' suggests the end of foreign domination. It prefigures the unity of believers in one faith.

verses.text: Look upon Zion, the city of our appointed festivals! Your eyes will see Jerusalem, an undisturbed habitation, a tent that shall not be removed; its stakes will never be pulled up, nor any of its cords broken.
verses.comment: Jerusalem is pictured as secure and eternal—a prophetic image of the redeemed community of God, which is unshakeable and enduring (see Revelation 21:2).

verses.text: But there the LORD in majesty will be for us a place of broad rivers and streams, where no galley with oars can go, nor mighty ship can pass.
verses.comment: God himself is the protection and provision for his people. The water imagery recalls Eden and the river of life in Revelation, emphasizing God’s presence as the source of life.

verses.text: For the LORD is our judge, the LORD is our lawgiver, the LORD is our king; he will save us.
verses.comment: God as Judge, Lawgiver, and King points to the fullness of divine authority, all fulfilled in Christ. This verse teaches that ultimate salvation is found in submitting to God's authority and law (see James 4:12).

verses.text: Your tackle hangs loose; it cannot hold the mast firm in its place, or keep the sail spread out. Then prey and abundant spoil are divided; even the lame take the prey.
verses.comment: The enemies’ ships are ruined; God’s people share in the victory and spoils, even the weakest among them—a sign of God’s complete deliverance.

verses.text: And no inhabitant will say, "I am sick"; the people who dwell in it will be forgiven their iniquity.
verses.comment: The forgiveness of sins brings healing and wholeness, echoing the connection Jesus makes between healing and forgiveness (see Matthew 9:2-6). The vision is both physical and spiritual—a community united in faith, sacraments, and divine grace.
